channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Concerns over political influence at health boards if overhaul proceeds
item.description: A former Waikato District Health Board member, who admits he landed an earlier public health role thanks to his contacts, is worried about political patronage if a health system proposal goes ahead.

item.title: Police halt recruitment after large increase in applications
item.description: More than 4000 people are in the recruitment process and about 600 people are applying to join each month, according to police.

item.title: Government unveils $390m subsidy for employers training apprentices
item.description: A new government subsidy will pay employers up to $16,000 for each new apprentice they train from August.

item.title: Auckland family kept separated by visa denials: 'We should be allowed to be together'
item.description: An Auckland mother whose partner has been waiting nearly a year for a visa to meet their baby is appalled a nanny for an America's Cup team has been granted a visa ahead of her child's father.

item.title: Pedestrian seriously injured after being hit by train in Matamata
item.description: A person is in a critical condition after being hit by a train in Matamata.

item.title: Foreigners in New Zealand offered relief, but no cash payments
item.description: Foreigners left high and dry due to the Covid-19 crisis will now be able to apply for food, clothing, blankets and accommodation from a new assistance programme.

item.title: Sentry Taitoko inquest ends six years after death in police cell
item.description: The mother of a young man who died in an Auckland police cell six years ago says it has been a long wait for answers.

item.title: Health Minister suspends compassionate exemptions from quarantine
item.description: Clark has told RNZ's Checkpoint he has asked for all compassionate exemptions from quarantine to be temporarily suspended as a result of the two latest cases of Covid-19.

item.title: De La Salle students urged not to retaliate after brawl, stabbing
item.description: An Auckland school is urging its students not to retaliate after a brawl left two teenagers with injuries - one of them with a stab wound.

item.title: Two new Covid-19 cases in NZ visited dying parent - Bloomfield
item.description: The two new cases of Covid-19 in New Zealand were women aged in their 30s and 40s who visited a dying parent in Wellington under compassionate grounds, Dr Ashley Bloomfield says.

item.title: Police Commmissioner proposes restructure of top tier
item.description: Police Commissioner Andrew Coster has released a proposal to re-design the organisation's executive structure.

item.title: Watercare uses emergency powers to get extra 15m litres of water per day
item.description: Auckland Council's water company is using emergency powers to pull a further 15 million litres of water day from the Waikato River.

item.title: Government allowed 26 Rocket Lab employees into New Zealand
item.description: The exemption for Rocket Lab, to support three launches, falls in the same category that allowed a film crew for an Avatar sequel to enter New Zealand.

item.title: Man who deliberately sneezed at shoppers fined
item.description: A Christchurch man who filmed himself coughing and sneezing at supermarket customers during the nation-wide lockdown has been fined $750.

item.title: Firearms reform set to progress in Parliament
item.description: Senior Labour ministers are playing down any influence coalition partner New Zealand First had on changes to firearms law, soon to be ushered through Parliament.

item.title: Parent wants Marist College to meet with families over racism
item.description: A parent at Marist College in Auckland say the school needs to meet with families and address accusations of racism at the school.

item.title: 'No way' Oranga Tamariki allowed to take babies from hospital - Waitematā DHB
item.description: A Māori trust and a senior health board member claim they have stopped Oranga Tamariki taking children into state care at Waitākere Hospital this morning.

item.title: OMV signals commitment to Taranaki with $15m refurbishment
item.description: OMV New Zealand is to spend $15 million refurbishing its new headquarters in New Plymouth, a move the oil and gas company says underscores its long-term commitment to Taranaki.
